# Abstract of project proposal (Maximum 2000 characters including spaces)

While hardware making is getting professionalised in academia, and while hardware maker communities have gotten organised during the last years, there is presently no system to assess the quality of that work, and no recognition system for researchers building open, FAIR hardware. We will pool expertise in hardware evaluation at the TU, academic hardware making at the FU and scholarly communication and data management at the HU, and tackle this important problematic. With this practice oriented project, the Berlin university Alliance will become an orchestrating center in the development of novel standards and tools for hardware documentation and publication.

### Hardware in academia

While the DFG kodex `r citep("https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3923602")` , the guideline 7 states that the quality insurance of published research outputs used must be explained. The Kodex does not mention hardware, although hardware creation (and especicially open source hardware) has been a large part of the research process in many different disciplines.

- Hardware in academia (TL)
  - role of hardware in academia
  - hardware dissemination
  - a career in (open source) hardware
  - existing communities

- non-traditional research output publication (JC)
  - data and FAIR principles (relation to open data and open source hardware) 
  - software and software citation group
  - contributor lists and CREDIT
  - RRID use for reagents and hardware
- Hardware documentation and open next (RM)
  - DIN
  - wiki review system


In order to build an recognition system for hardware, we will seek inspiration in data and software publication system, that have been developed  during the last decade.
While articles production is still the major source of recognition for researchers, other, non-traditional research outputs are indeed starting to be recognized (see guideline 13 of the DFG kodex). In particular, there are new publication pathways for research data and research software, via specific platforms that use datacite to get a doi and proper metadata. The specialised platforms run rather independently of the usual journals articles presenting the research results. Citations are dealt via the scholarly communication ecosystem, but citation to the original data or software (instead of the first article using it) is recommended by a RDA group `r citep("https://doi.org/10.12688/f1000research.26932.2")`. 

These pathways are coming with specialised quality insurance mechansims. Data curation is following FAIR principles, originally developped by the FORCE11 coomunity `r citep("10.1038/sdata.2016.18")`, and software review are run on git platforms, for example in the journal of Open Source Software (JOSS, ISSN 2475-9066), following community standards.

The hardware makers communities are organising themselves, but their work is not yet recognised as being an integral part of the academic success. There is still few representation of these communities in larger organisation devoted to scholarly communication (FORCE11) or data management (RDA: Research Data Alliance). 


### Project objectives

We want to create a prototype for a hardware publication system, in order to build the foundation for a recognition of hardware making skills in academia. It will include a certification system specific for FAIR and open hardware. We will work with open indexing system (datacite) to adapt publication pathways used for data and software. This system will explore new incentives (independent of journals) for the production of better hardware documentation in academia, irrespective of the research domain. 

In addition, we want to provide researchers with tools to guide their work along the whole process of open and FAIR hardware design. In particular, we will write a guide will be provided as an open book, using a technology similar to the turing way book `r citep("10.5281/zenodo.3233853")`.
In order to extract best practices in hardware collaborative creation, we will analyse  current workflows in use, their successes and shortcomings. In addition,
we will dissect the  certification process of some chosen hardware pieces in neuroscience, robotics and medicine. 
This open project will be performed in close collaboration with FORCE11, `datacite,` the open source hardware association, and the Gathering for Open Science Hardware communities.



![summary figure](https://github.com/open-science-promoters/BUAgrant_OSH/raw/main/visualabstract_buacall.png)
  >Fig.1 In order to build a hardware publication platform, a guide for best practice in collaborative and transparent hardware development, and publish specific hardware using these tools, three groups from three Berlin universities will collaborate. While each work package (WP) will be performed collaboratively, each group is specifically responsible for one of them. We will base our work on existing tools and recommendation coming for open science practices, FAIR data principles and software citation, to build a pioneering system. Discussion and collaboration with the gathering of open science hardware and open source hardware association communities will be fostered along the project. We will also promote a discussion on hardware publication and citation inside the FORCE11 networks.
